Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: MAPS - MetaAnalogy via Performance Specification

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative research will define a new approach for retrieving useful analogies for innovation based on the relevant performance characteristics of critical functions. Analogy matching is made possible by the novel incorporation of Non Uniform Rational B-spline (NURBs) based metamodels that enable efficient representation of critical function performance. These metamodels are obtained from simulations, engineering models (such as bond graphs) and/or experimental data collections. This approach will enable multiple analogies to be presented to the designer with a quantified match quality metric related to the desired performance benefit to the design. The impact of this approach for inspiring novel designs will be measured through controlled experiments measuring the impact of the MetaAnalogy via Performance Specification (MAPS) technique at both the conceptual design phase and throughout the design process. Working prototypes from the experiments will allow for direct quantification of performance.

Engineering innovation is critical to meet a vast array of challenges including the grand engineering challenges of the 21st century in the form of energy and environmental solutions. If successful, results of the research will provide a critical foundation for new approaches to analogy retrieval based on quantitative performance measures along with function for use in education and industry. Class modules applying MAPS to analogy-based innovation will be created. Workshops integrated with webinars on MAPS and design by analogy will be used to disseminate research results beyond the educational sector and to provide necessary educational tools to bring design by analogy and quantification via Metamodeling into the classroom.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Engineering innovation drives continued economic growth, overcoming current societal problems, and reduced environmental impact.  Grasping for ideas, people can struggle to find solutions to a problem. They might be limited by their particular domain knowledge and lack access to ideas that could actually help them to find an innovative solution.  One method that has been very successful in helping engineering traverse from one domain to another to find innovative solutions is design-by-analogy. Design-by-analogy from nature and existing products is a well-documented approach to enhancing engineering innovation, but effectively identifying analogies from outside to problem domains is very challenging.  Design-by-analogy occurs when designers identify solutions in nature or existing products.  For example, Velcro’s design was based on the close examination of burrs. 

To better support engineering innovation, the project developed a novel approach to analogy retrieval.  Due to the critical role of product performance metrics in product design, the analogy retrieval approach focused on this unmet need.   The project created frameworks for organizing the myriad of technical performance metrics used in engineering design (e.g. efficiency, cost, weight, etc.). Such organizational frameworks are needed for the implementation of computational tools that can retrieve relevant analogies using performance metrics. The project embedded this organization in a software tool called Design Repository & Analogy Computation via Unit-Language Analysis (DRACULA) tool. The program performs dimensional analysis matching using function, flow, and performance descriptions with an evolving database repository of design analogies.  Functions are an abstraction of what a device must do not its physical form.  For example, the function of a battery is to store energy.  Flows are the energy, materials, and signals which pass through a product.  A functional model abstracts the functions and flows of a product. 

The development and refinement of DRACULA were guided by empirical product studies and engineering design studies. A study of analogy-inspired products guided the development and found that the vast majority of analogies improved product performance, but did not add functions to the device. This indicates the importance of performance matches in retrieving analogies. Through empirical product studies and design studies, this project also identified the key concepts of Critical Functionality, Common Functions, Common Flows and Critical Flows. Not all functions within a functional model have the same level of significance to the performance of the design. Selecting an appropriate form solution for Critical Functions significantly affects the performance of the overall design.  Just as some functions are more important within the functional model than other functions, some flows are more significant to the performance of the design solution than other flows.  A study of over a hundred products identified common functions and flows found in electromechanical consumer products.  This research demonstrates that analogy databases can have greater impact if they are first populated with Common Critical Functions and Flows. The DRACULA tool has been initially populated with devices that contain Common Critical Functions and Flow. 

Many broader impacts also resulted from this project. Over  ten conference papers were published, three journal papers were published with an additional  journal paper in review and one more journal paper in preparation. Five undergraduates performed research at the Georgia Institute of Technology and six at the Colorado Schools of Mines. One PhD graduate thesis and two MS theses resulted from this project and additional graduate students participated in the project.  Four of the graduate students involved were female PhD students, three of which have the intention of becoming faculty.  This project developed frameworks for performance metrics and concepts such as Critical Functions and Flows that can be leveraged by other projects.  It also provided additional fundamental knowledge about how designers leverage analogies, their needs, and potential approaches for enhancing the design process.
